channel.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
channel.description:
Hello world :D,
Im fairly new here and this is my first post so here goes :rolleyes:
Nevertheless I am having a bit of trouble with Java, I recently bought 'Java: A Beginner's Guide Fourth Edition, [i]By Herbert Schildt[/i], it is a brilliant book and a good buy in my honest opinion, ( Lucky that my friends recommended it to me :) ) however it is just that I am stuck on the 'Increments and Decrements' section.
It states that you can either put the ++ or -- at prefix or postfix, I get that but but then it proceeds to state it can sometimes matter which way you put it, it says something about the precedence(sp?) but I unfortunately do not know what this is, I have researched numerous times on the matter but could not get my head round all the jargon and vocabulary used in describing it. If someone could shed some light on how to help me in a such a way that I could understand it, I would be very grateful to whoever can help me :)
Thanks, Your newest member Spicy Nova :D

item.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

It is necessary, try removing it and running.

It wont function properly mate. Mostly because it’s used once to access iastore, and once to save to the field; Thus it had to be duplicated on the stack.

Read full topic

item.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I haven’t done any tests on it, but according to my professor ++i is faster than i++ because i++ allocates another variable and swaps the value into it, while ++i just increments the original value. It would be interesting to test though.

Read full topic

item.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[code]public class Test {
public void after(int value) {
value++;
}

public void before(int value) {
    ++value;
}

}[/code]

[code]james@laptop:~$ javac Test.java
james@laptop:~$ javap -c Test
Compiled from “Test.java”
public class Test extends java.lang.Object{
public Test();
Code:
0: aload_0
1: invokespecial #1; //Method java/lang/Object."":()V
4: return

public void after(int);
Code:
0: iinc 1, 1
3: return

public void before(int);
Code:
0: iinc 1, 1
3: return

}[/code]

[code]public class Test {
int value;

public void after() {
    value++;
}

public void before() {
    ++value;
}

}[/code]

[code]james@laptop:~$ javap -c Test
Compiled from “Test.java”
public class Test extends java.lang.Object{
int value;

public Test();
Code:
0: aload_0
1: invokespecial #1; //Method java/lang/Object."":()V
4: return

public void after();
Code:
0: aload_0
1: dup
2: getfield #2; //Field value:I
5: iconst_1
6: iadd
7: putfield #2; //Field value:I
10: return

public void before();
Code:
0: aload_0
1: dup
2: getfield #2; //Field value:I
5: iconst_1
6: iadd
7: putfield #2; //Field value:I
10: return

}[/code]
maybe i am miscounting ;D but they both seem to use the exact same number of instructions

Read full topic

item.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
item.dc:creator: @Firion Firion
item.description:
@Firion wrote:

[quote=“capndurk, post:1, topic:80125”][quote author=Firion link=topic=117566.msg1157625#msg1157625 date=1176608584]
Tip by io9:
The only time i++ and ++i are different is in for loops.

if you do for(int i = 0; i == 50; ++i), then it will add to i before beginning the loop, and if you do i++ it’ll add to i after the loop. same with --i and i-- only it’ll subtract before and after the loop, respectively.
[/quote]

no, firion, all of what you said is wrong. first of all, i++ and ++i are used in regular statements to achieve different effects. secondly, the last expression in a for loop is executed after it loops, meaning using one over the other would not change i at any point during the loop.[/quote]
Actually it was io9 who said that, also, he said his aunt told him that.

Read full topic

item.title: Confuzzled - Increments And Decrements
item.dc:creator: @Firion Firion
item.description:
@Firion wrote:

Tip by io9:
The only time i++ and ++i are different is in for loops.

if you do for(int i = 0; i == 50; ++i), then it will add to i before beginning the loop, and if you do i++ it’ll add to i after the loop. same with --i and i-- only it’ll subtract before and after the loop, respectively.

Read full topic
